name: Shigeru Mizuki
injury: The explosion caused severe burns, and he lost his left arm.
story: He later became known for his works that depict his life as a hibakusha (atomic bomb survivor), including his autobiographical manga Onward Towards Our Noble Deaths

name: Sadako Sasaki
injury: Although she initially seemed unharmed, she developed leukemia a few years later due to radiation exposure.

name: Keiji Nakazawa
story: He survived, but his father, sister, and brother were killed.

name: Keiko Ogura
story: The blast knocked her unconscious, and when she awoke, she witnessed unimaginable destruction and suffering.

name: Kiyoshi Tanimoto
story: In the aftermath, he tirelessly worked to help other survivors, guiding them to safer areas and assisting with basic needs.

name: Tsutomu Yamaguchi
story: He was in Hiroshima on a business trip when the bomb fell. Despite being seriously injured, he returned to his home city of Nagasaki—only to experience the second atomic bombing three days later. Surviving both.

name: Sumiteru Taniguchi
injury: He was badly burned by the bomb’s intense heat. He spent years in hospitals recovering and suffered chronic pain for the rest of his life.

name: Akihiro Takahashi
injury: Severe burns and radiation-related health problems

name: Dr. Shuntaro Hida
injury: Minor immediate physical injuries, but exposed to radiation
story: In the aftermath, he treated countless radiation victims and spent decades researching the long-term health effects.

name: Yoshito Matsushige
story: Though injured, he managed to photograph some of the only existing images of the devastated city in the immediate aftermath.

name: Hideko Tamura Snider
story: She lost her mother in the bombing and endured years of emotional and physical recovery.

name: Hiroko Watanabe
injury: Although spared severe burns, she struggled with radiation-related illnesses for decades.

name: Koko Kondo
story: An infant at the time of the bombing, Koko Kondo survived in her home near Hiroshima’s center.
